pages.title: Page 1
pages.text: Once upon a time, there was a little girl who lived in a village near the woods. Everyone called her Little Red Riding Hood because she always wore a red cape with a hood. Her grandmother made it for her, and it was her favorite thing to wear.

pages.title: Page 2
pages.text: One day, Little Red's mother said, "Your grandmother is sick. Can you take this basket of food to her? She lives on the other side of the woods." "Yes, Mother!" said Little Red. "I will go right away!" Mother packed the basket with: - Bread - Butter - A slice of cake - Some fresh eggs

pages.title: Page 3
pages.text: "Now listen," said Mother. "Stay on the pathway. Don't talk to strangers. Go straight to Grandmother's house. Don't stop in the woods!" "I won't, Mother!" said Little Red. "I promise!" She put on her red hood, picked up the basket, and headed into the woods.

pages.title: Page 4
pages.text: The woods were beautiful. Little Red walked along the pathway. She saw: - Birds singing in the trees - Flowers growing by the edge of the path - Butterflies dancing in the air "What a nice day!" said Little Red. She hummed a little song as she walked.

pages.title: Page 5
pages.text: Suddenly, a big, gray wolf stepped onto the pathway! "Good morning, little girl," said the wolf in a gentle voice. Little Red stopped. She knew she should not talk to strangers. But the wolf seemed nice... Wrong choice, Little Red!

pages.title: Page 6
pages.text: "Where are you going?" asked the wolf. "To my grandmother's house," said Little Red. "She lives on the other side of the woods. She is sick, so I am bringing her food." "How nice of you!" said the wolf. But inside, he was thinking: *"Mmm! A little girl AND her grandmother! I could eat them both!"*

pages.title: Page 7
pages.text: "Why don't you pick some flowers for your grandmother?" said the wolf. "Look! There are beautiful flowers over there by that hedge!" "Oh! Good idea!" said Little Red. She left the pathway and went to pick flowers. Wrong again, Little Red!

pages.title: Page 8
pages.text: As soon as Little Red left the pathway, the wolf ran ahead! He knew a quick shortcut through the woods. "I will get to Grandmother's house first!" he said. "Then I will eat Grandmother, and when Little Red arrives, I will eat her too!" The wolf laughed his wicked laugh. Chapter 1 ends here! What will happen next?

pages.title: Page 9
pages.text: The wolf arrived at Grandmother's little house. Knock, knock, knock! (Remember: knock has a silent K!) "Who is there?" called Grandmother from inside. "It's me, Little Red!" said the wolf in a high, fake voice. (He was trying to trick Grandmother!)

pages.title: Page 10
pages.text: "The door is unlocked, dear," said Grandmother. "Come inside!" The wolf opened the door and went inside. Poor Grandmother! She was lying in bed. She was old and weak. When she saw the wolf, she tried to scream‚Äî But it was too late!

pages.title: Page 11
pages.text: The wolf gobbled up Grandmother in one big gulp! (Don't worry‚Äîin the real story, she's OK later!) Then the wolf put on Grandmother's nightgown. He put on her nightcap. He put on her glasses. He climbed into her bed and pulled up the covers. "Now I will wait for Little Red!" he said.

pages.title: Page 12
pages.text: Meanwhile, Little Red was still picking flowers. She picked: - White daisies - Yellow buttercups - Purple violets She made a beautiful bouquet. "Grandmother will love these!" she said. Then she remembered: "Oh! I should hurry! Mother said not to stop in the woods!" She ran back to the pathway and hurried to Grandmother's house.

pages.title: Page 13
pages.text: At last, Little Red arrived at the little house. Knock, knock, knock! "Who is there?" called a voice from inside. (It was the wolf's voice, but Little Red didn't know that!) "It's me, Little Red!" she said. "Come inside, dear!" said the voice. Little Red opened the door and went in.

pages.title: Page 14
pages.text: The room was dark. Little Red walked to the bed. She could see someone under the covers. "Hello, Grandmother!" said Little Red. "I brought you food and flowers!" "Thank you, dear," said the wolf in his fake old-woman voice. "Come closer so I can see you!" Little Red came closer. Chapter 2 ends here! What will Little Red notice?

pages.title: Page 15
pages.text: Little Red looked at "Grandmother." Something was wrong. "Grandmother," she said, "What big ears you have!" "The better to hear you with, my dear!" said the wolf. Little Red came a little closer.

pages.title: Page 16
pages.text: "Grandmother," said Little Red, "What big eyes you have!" "The better to see you with, my dear!" said the wolf. Little Red felt nervous. She took a step back.

pages.title: Page 17
pages.text: "Grandmother," said Little Red, "What big teeth you have!" The wolf grinned a big, wicked grin. "The better to EAT you with!" he roared! And he jumped out of bed! Little Red screamed! "HELP! HELP! It's a WOLF!"

pages.title: Page 18
pages.text: The wolf chased Little Red around the room! She ran behind the table! She ran behind the chair! "Help! Someone help me!" she cried. The wolf was fast! He was getting closer and closer! Little Red was in terrible danger! Chapter 3 ends here! Will someone save her?

pages.title: Page 19
pages.text: Just then‚Äî A woodcutter was walking by outside! (A woodcutter is someone who cuts down trees. Woodcutter is a compound word: wood + cutter = woodcutter!) He heard Little Red screaming! "That sounds like trouble!" he said. He ran to the house with his axe!

pages.title: Page 20
pages.text: The woodcutter burst through the door! He saw the wolf chasing Little Red! "Stop right there, wolf!" he shouted. The wolf turned around. When he saw the big woodcutter with the big axe, the wolf got scared! "Uh oh!" said the wolf.

pages.title: Page 21
pages.text: The wolf tried to run away! But the woodcutter was quick! He caught the wolf! "Spit out Grandmother, you wicked wolf!" said the woodcutter. The wolf had to spit out Grandmother. She was OK! (A little wet, but OK!)

pages.title: Page 22
pages.text: The woodcutter chased the wolf out of the house. "Get out of here!" he shouted. "And don't come back!" The wolf ran into the woods as fast as he could. He never came back. Little Red and Grandmother were safe!

pages.title: Page 23
pages.text: "Thank you for saving us!" said Little Red. "You are very brave!" said Grandmother. "I am just glad you are both safe!" said the woodcutter. Grandmother got out of bed. Little Red unpacked the basket of food. They all sat down and had a nice meal together.

pages.title: Page 24
pages.text: After the meal, the woodcutter walked Little Red home. When they arrived, Mother was so happy to see her! "Did you stay on the pathway?" asked Mother. Little Red hung her head. "No, Mother," she said. "I didn't. I talked to the wolf. I left the pathway to pick flowers. I'm sorry. I shouldn't have done that."

pages.title: Page 25
pages.text: "I'm just glad you're safe," said Mother. "I learned my lesson!" said Little Red. "From now on, I will: - Stay on the pathway - Not talk to strangers - Listen to what you say!" "That's my smart girl!" said Mother. And Little Red never went into the woods alone again. The lesson: Listen to good advice! Stay safe! Don't talk to strangers! Practice reading with different voices: - Little Red: Soft, sweet, innocent - Mother: Caring, warning - Wolf (as wolf): Sneaky, sly - Wolf (as Grandma): High, fake, trying to trick - Grandmother: Old, gentle, weak - Woodcutter: Strong, brave, heroic Act it out with different voices! At the end of each chapter, we asked: "What will happen next?" Were your predictions right? - Did you think the wolf would eat Grandma? ‚úì - Did you think Little Red would notice something wrong? ‚úì - Did you think someone would save them? ‚úì Good readers make predictions!
